Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Modularity in forelimb motor output and cervical interneuronal firing

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the population of individuals with a complete cervical spinal cord injury, the most desired medical advance is the recovery of arm and hand use.  Toward this end, the force output at the wrist elicited by intraspinal microstimulation (ISMS) was investigated. The force output direction and magnitude at several locations can be combined to form a map of the force output across space, which can be referred to as a force field, an example of which is shown here (line length represents force output magnitude, measured in newtons). While previous research in the primate arm has examined muscle recruitment or movement kinematics, this is the first time to our knowledge that the changes in muscle recruitment and force output have been measured as the configuration of the arm was systematically changed.

 Two macaque monkeys were chronically implanted at the C5-7 level with electrode arrays and EMG electrodes implanted in the left shoulder and arm. Under anesthesia, the arm was moved throughout its normal range of motion lateral to the body and stimulation was applied to either one or two electrode sites. In some cases, force fields were evoked that contained an equilibrium point or line (the red line in the figure) where the force output was zero with restorative forces being generated at other positions, while in other cases the field was uniformly directed as may be the case for direct recruitment of motor pools. Further, each stimulation site evoked activity in particular sets of muscles, or synergies, which were in some cases dependent on the configuration of the arm.

Simultaneously stimulating two sites sometimes led to a winner-take-all or non-linear response. In some cases, stimulation at one site inhibited the ability of the second site to evoke movement even after stimulation of the first site had ceased, evidence that a long-term pattern of interneuronal activity was being evoked. Further, simultaneous stimulation at some sites lead to an arm movement of greater force than the sum of the force output patterns of the two sites individually. However, in some cases the output field of the simultaneous stimulation was nearly exactly the summation of the individual fields. We were also able to monitor the viability of using an implanted electrode array for intraspinal microstimulation over several months, tracking both the stimulation strengths required to elicit force output at the wrist as well as the field generated by that stimulation strength. This has required a continuing collaboration between myself and one of the graduate students at the host institution.

From these results, there is evidence of an internal model of the arm present in the cervical spinal cord, the existence of which will impact the development and function of a neuroprosthetic device designed to restore arm movement. There are also regions of the spinal cord, however, where internal processing seems to be at a minimum, and can be much more readily be used in such a device. We also showed that an implanted device can be stable over the long term.

I also had some time to take in some of Japan's history and natural beauty during the program.
